metadata.titleEn: Permafrost soil bacteria in Barrow Peninsula, Arctic (2015)
metadata.description: This data includes the soil microbial composition data in permafrost of different ages in Barrow area of the Arctic. It can be used to explore the response of soil microorganisms to the thawing in permafrost of different ages. This data is generated by high through-put sequencing using the earth microbiome project primers are 515f – 806r. The region amplified is the V4 hypervariable region, and the sequencing platform is Illumina hiseq PE250; This data is used in the articles published in cryosphere, Permafrost thawing exhibits a greater influence on bacterial richness and community structure than permafrost age in Arctic permafrost soils. The Cryosphere, 2020, 14, 3907–3916, https://doi.org/10.5194/tc-14-3907-2020https://doi.org/10.5194/tc-14-3907-2020 . This data can also be used for the comparative analysis of soil microorganisms across the three poles.
metadata.instructions:
The dataset contains two file types: sequence data (.fastq) and OTU table (.xlsx).
File name: the name of the sequence data file is: permafrost age + thaw status+replication ID.read.fq , permafrost age is the age of the perfofrost, including young (< 50 years old), medium (< 300 years old), old (< 3000 years old) and ancient (3000 – 5000 years old); thaw status is the permafrost state, including: permanently frozen, transition and active; replication ID includes 1-4; read is the sequencing direction, including R1 (forward) and R2 (reverse)
Data reading method: the sequence data can be opened by text program (such as Notepad), and the main content is sequencing base quality; the processed OTU table can be opened by MS Excel, and the subject content is OTU table based on 97% sequence identity and species classification information.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to study bacterial community structures in permafrost soils?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to study bacterial community structures in permafrost soils involves amplicon sequencing with primers from the Earth Microbiome Project, specifically using primers 515F–806R to target the V4 region, and sequencing on an Illumina Hiseq PE250 platform.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of bacterial species composition in Arctic permafrost soils of different ages collected through amplicon sequencing?
Feature Specification.Answer: bacterial species composition data, varying ages, Earth Microbiome Project standard primers 515F–806R, V4 region, Illumina Hiseq PE250 platform, quality control at least Q30 level

Comparison.Question: How do the bacterial community compositions in permafrost soils of different ages compare when analyzed using amplicon sequencing with the Earth Microbiome Project standard primers versus other sequencing techniques?
Comparison.Answer: The bacterial species composition data from the Barrow region permafrost soils uses amplicon sequencing with Earth Microbiome Project standard primers 515F–806R, targeting the V4 region, and sequenced on an Illumina Hiseq PE250 platform. This method involves quality control ensuring at least Q30 level, and is suitable for exploring differences in bacterial species in permafrost soils of different ages.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences on bacterial richness and community structure when permafrost soils in Arctic regions undergo thawing, considering different ages of permafrost?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Thawing of permafrost soils in Arctic regions has a greater influence on bacterial richness and community structure than the age of the permafrost. This is observed in the bacterial species composition data collected from permafrost soils of different ages in the Arctic Barrow area, using amplicon sequencing with the Earth Microbiome Project standard primers.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of obtaining bacterial species composition data from Arctic permafrost soils of varying ages?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to explore the response of soil microorganisms to permafrost thawing and to understand the differences in soil bacterial communities across permafrost of different ages. This data can also be used for comparative analysis of soil microorganisms across polar regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures and technologies are used to ensure the quality and reliability of bacterial species composition data collected from permafrost soil samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data is collected using amplicon sequencing with Earth Microbiome Project standard primers 515F–806R, targeting the V4 region, and sequenced on the Illumina Hiseq PE250 platform. Quality control measures ensure the data reaches at least a Q30 quality level.

Enablement.Question: What sequencing technologies and quality control measures enable the accurate collection of bacterial species composition data in Arctic permafrost soils?
Enablement.Answer: The use of amplicon sequencing with Earth Microbiome Project standard primers 515F–806R on the Illumina Hiseq PE250 platform, combined with quality control measures ensuring at least Q30 level, enables the accurate collection of bacterial species composition data in Arctic permafrost soils.
